thread.title: Iowa City West’s athleticism on display in pummeling of Dubuque Hempstead
thread.title_full: Iowa City West’s athleticism on display in pummeling of Dubuque Hempstead

title: Iowa City West’s athleticism on display in pummeling of Dubuque Hempstead
text:
Iowa City West's athleticism on display in pummeling of Dubuque Hempstead Iowa City West's athleticism on display in pummeling of Dubuque Hempstead Trojans move to 2-0 in district play with 63-27 win Photos View Slideshow Iowa City West’s Devontae Lane (6) returns the opening kickoff for a touchdown against Dubuque Hempstead in a class 4A high school football game at West High School in Iowa City on Friday, Oct. 9, 2015. (Adam Wesley/The Gazette) Most Popular October 9, 2015 | 11:07 pm 
IOWA CITY — If at first you don’t score a touchdown, try again. 
Oliver Martin and Iowa City West did just that Friday night in a 63-27 Class 4A District 7 win over Dubuque Hempstead. West improved to 2-5 overall, 2-0 in district play. Hempstead fell to 5-2, 1-1. 
Denied the end zone on a big punt return late in the first half, Martin responded by returning a punt 79 yards for a touchdown early in the second half. 
“We’ve got playmakers, we just need to get them the ball,” said Trojans head coach Garret Hartwig. 
Later in the half, Martin was stopped on a loss of six yards. The next play, Trojans quarterback Alex Henderson bought a little time and hit Martin for a 75-yard touchdown catch. 
“The key for our guys is to just make it simple and play fast,” Hartwig said. “Just let them do what they do and stay out of the way.” 
Big plays dominated the first half for West. Devontae Lane opened the game with a 79-yard kickoff return for a touchdown. Just three minutes later, Henderson connected with Martin on a 67-yard touchdown pass to put the Trojans up 14-0. 
“Those two (Henderson and Martin) are incredible athletes,” Hartwig said. “They’ve been in big games their whole life and are used to making plays. 
The Mustang defense kept their composure and held the Trojans to just 36 yards rushing in the first half. After the long touchdown pass early, the Mustangs contained the Trojans to just 97 yards passing. 
The Hempstead offense found a groove in the passing game. Cole Muehring completed his first five passes for 80 yards. Tay Collins got the Mustangs on the board with a 28-yard touchdown run. 
“We made some good throws and some good catches,” said Hempstead head coach Bob McIntyre. “We had some good yards after the catch.” 
Hempstead continued to battle in the second half, but the Trojans offense was just too much. Your Next Prep Football Articles
